bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK - The United
States Steel Foundation has an
nounced a gift of $4,000 in
operating aid to predominantly
Negro colleges. including all
members Of the United Negro
College Fund, for l964-65. This
brings the ll-year total Of such
aid to about 100000. In addi-
ton, for capital. project. and
other needs, $2l8,000 has been
made available for Negro educa-
tion during the same period.


This year further commit
ment of up to 100000 has been
made, the bulk of which goes to
the UNCF $50 million capital
campaign. The current and past

aid to Negro education. includ-
ing grants for both operating and
special needs. now totals more
than three quarters of million
dollars.


The Negro schools receiving
aid are among $50 institutions
and % organizations aided by
the Steel Foundation this year.
In this connection, Roger Blough.
chairman of the u. S. Steel Foun-
dation's board of trustees COM
mented, lit is timely to note that
u. S. Steel has long tried to carry
a just share Of responsibility for
advancing the role of the Negro
in American life.

NEW YORK During the past
ten years. American Negroes
have broadened their travel hor-
lions to include the Caribbean
and Europe. AS lower fares be-
come effective no part Of the
world will be too far for those
with dreams of far-away places
and moderate budgets, stated a
leading travel executive.


Celebrating his tenth anniver-
sary as the head Of a New York
travel firm, Hilton G. Hill. pres
ident of the firm bearing his
name, has become specialist
in international travel planning.


Considered "America's most
experienced Negro-owned and
operated travel agency" the Hill
firm operates from midtown
Manhattan offic


And Street in New York City.


Hill formed Hilton G. Hill,
Inc, in Bermuda in le49. and
transferred it to New York City
in 1854. In these ten years,
according to MIR. Hill, while bus
and train tours have remained
as the most organized travel by
Negroes in the United States,
there has been a definite trend

Top row efCity councilman Jay Hyde presents keys
the city Emmett Harrison.


the PISA Emmett Harrison.
state president Smith, Mrs. Buena V. Kelly
secretary obson Reynolds grand exalted ruler and Mrs.
Nette B. Smith, grand DIT. ruler, of New York City.


RghCrowng of the Queen PSA Emmett Harrison and Mrs.
MEroy Carnaon Lady of Grand Canyon Temple


leftAt the banquet Sammie Warren. newly elected
PRESIDENT Backshear ruler Grand Canyon
Temple Mrs. Bertha Trpe organizer
auxiliary of the PISA.


ddleLng their voices members of Grand Canyon
Temple choir during the neurology services.


Mesdames Nina Burton Ruby Backhear Clara Long,
Mccoy Mary Gertrude Clements Ciny Weaver Essie
Richie, Lillian Fit and Esther McEroy.


RighMrs Maple Lee Pratt. Mr.. and Mrs. c. l. Smith relax
after the festivities.

Dear Mr.. Banks:


Renew my subscription for two
years. Wishing you many more
years of continued success.


Mrs. B. w. Williams


Vallejo, California
Mr.. Banks:


do appreciate everyone that
has helped me since my home
burned on the 18th Of April.
Thanks again.


Mrs. Ardelia Wilson


8l4 W. Yuma

Mrs. Dolores Cioggins, OF Buff
falo. N.Y.. and Mrs. Winifred
Allen, of Detroit. Mich. are
houseguests of Mrs. Eddie
Jay. They plan to motor to
Mexico for the holiday.


Mrs. Eloise White is going to
relax for a few weeks at Laguna
Beach, Calf.


An old fashioned barbecue will
be sponsored on July Fourth at
Eastlake Park by the Salt VAL
ley Lodge IA FAM. ]. E. John
son Is the president.


Departing this week for an
extended visit in the midwest and
east are MIR. and Mrs. Rogers
Johnson. They will see the
Worlds Fair.


MISS Joan Cochran jetted to
Los Angeles to visit family and
friends for the Fourth Of July.


Mrs. M. Lamb, Of Frest, Mss.
is visiting her sister. Mrs. Eliz-
abeth Turner and other relatives
in the city.


Miss Delois Henry and Frank
lin Pegram married July l. Her
parents are Mrs. Addie Doris
and Alden Henry.


The groom's mother is Mrs.
Anna Harris, of Pittsburg, Va.


MIR. and Mrs. Jerome Powell
went to Tucson to pick up their
son., John. who has been visiting
relatives there.


Mrs. Willie Lester. and daugh-
ter, Gertrude, of Los Angeles.
are visiting Mrs. Elizabeth Mich
OILS and relatives.


Mrs. Marg Bolton and Mrs.
Doris Neal are attending the
wedding of Miss Alice Jean Wash
ington in Tucson Saturday.


Everyone is happy that M. D.
King has returned from Las
Vegas.


The wait Of the year--A friend
of mine has been waiting for"
over 20 years to returnt to school.
She has recently enrolled in nurs-
ing school. Good Luck. I'm pull
ing for you.


We are expecting all Of our
friends and especially former
Debonairs at our annual Sadie
Hawkins dance Sat-, July 4th at
Abel Hall.


Congratulations to the men and
women Elks of Phoenix for host
ing a great PISA convention. We
all are proud of you. Hats Off
to the Elks.


Call me for items in this COL
umn at AL 8-05ll-daytime and
258-O005 evenings.

to transatlantic air and surface.
travel.


"While the conversion Of Ne
groes to glying has been slow,
it is nonetheless increasing"
stated Hill, "and today Negro
businessmen, vacationers. Peace
Corps representatives and gov
eminent officials are finding 1t
a safe, pleasant, and fast mode
of travel to foreign lands for
business and pleasure"


A former member Of the Ber-
muda Parliament (1953-1e58),
and currently president of the
Inter-American Travel Agents
Society QATAS). Hill believes
that with the lowest air fares In
years, the price advantage Will
afford many Negroes, where In
comes, while moderate. are
growing, the opportunity to visit
historical and pleasure sites in
Europe.


While rates to Europe will be
lower, Hill stated that rates to
the Caribbean are also being
reduced. The Caribbean has long
enjoyed a steadily increasing
traffic by Negroes. especially at
such times as Trinidad s Carni-
val.

LONDON-Pvt. O. w. Cowell,
a 26 yr. old jamaican. has be-
come the first Negro member Of
a British army regiment to stand
guard at Buckingham Palace.
